bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, July 27, 1900

div1.p: Reed describes the weather in Cuba. He teases Emilie Lawrence Reed, and anticipates his arrival home.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, July 27, 1900
div1.opener:
C1
B9
No.25.
Regards
to Jacob, Cora
& Carrie.
Don't eat up
all the cabbage,
Camp Columbia,
Quemados, Cuba,
July 27, 1900
Friday afternoon-
My Sweet Farmer-lady;
div1.p:
If one
half of the rain was falling on
our dear little hill side at Kee-
waydin that is now pouring
down on our parade, I
don't believe that the grass
or any thing else would have
cause to complain! No wonder
that vegetation flourishes here
during this season. We have
only had two rains to-day, but
for fear that things might get
dry before morning, we will
probably get another rain during the
night, just to “even things” up a
little, as it were! I wish that
tomorrow's mail would hurry up
and come along, as I haven't
had a word from my precious
little ranch-keeper since last
Monday- As dear daughter
didn't say anything about your
being “under the weather,” I
suppose that my sweet oomsey
was so busy with her flowers
that she forgot to write-
Hurry up and send another
along & I'll forgive the dear
lady that whom the rain-man de-
serted for so long a time!
It makes me very happy
to think that a Transport will
soon be here and that I can
start homeward to see
my precious girls again;
and to look into Sis
Mottsey's lilac eye, once
more, and hear her merry chuck-
le! Do pray, don't let Sis
Cyclone get sick before old
Brer Rabbit gets there. I
tell you, Miss Meadows, Miss
Motts and the gals must begin to
“slick up” a little, now that
old Brer Rabbit is going
to call soon and “make he
bow”! Get out your best
big and tucker and be prepared
to snicker & giggle and gicker
and sniggle! He! He! He!
By Jove, it was cool enough
before this shower came
up but now it is down-
right cold! Think of it's
being chilly in Cuba during
July! Don't it beat the Jews?
Saturday morning-28th. Get out of bed
lovie, dear, and stop that everlasting
snoozing! Here its 6.30 a.m. and the mail-
-man coming, & you still asleep! You
will change these slothful habits when
old Brer Rab gets there! The quarter-
master telegraphed, last evening, that
the Transport, Rawlins, sailed from N.Y.
yesterday (Friday) at 9 a.m., and as she is
a fast boat, she will reach Havana
Monday evening, and will probably sail
Tuesday afternoon. So that before my
sweet Farmer-lady gets this, her old
Mr Farmer-man will probably be on
the high seas ploughing his way to
New York- Won't that be fun, pro-
vided the sea isn't rough? I am
going to take my first bromide
powder, this morning- I still have
a little faith in the bromide though
not much, I must confess! Cool
& cloudy, this morning- Such a morning
as would make our grass boom!
Best love to Sis Mottsey & Helen- Give
little Sis Goose a good squeeze for her
father. Love and kisses for my precious
girls- Keep your faces clean-
